p: To understand how fast an epidemic spreads spatially, we examine the average distance of the infected nodes in network A from the center of the lattice as a function of time in Fig. 5. When p is small, the average distance gradually increases to the maximum distance at a low velocity. As p increases, epidemics can spread spatially all over the network with less time due to the addition of shortcuts. This finding is consistent with the results presented in Fig. 4(a).
